A number of years back I made a Halbach array using half inch cube magnets (parts B888-2PA-N52 and B888-2PE-N52 from K&J Magnetics), fastened together with a brass through rod and held in an aluminum channel to hold their orientation.  It produced something like 8,000 - 12,000 gauss on the strong side if I recall correctly.  I used it to wipe disk platters from disassembled hard drives.  It’s a weird sensation to feel the platters resist motion across the array, but not actually be magnetically stuck to the array.

Like the flat earth, I think videos that give credence to the idea of a hyperloop should come with a warning on the bottom. You cannot hold a vacuum over distances longer than a few hundred feet, the thermal expansion with the different parts along the tube would cause implosion and be ridiculously expensive. You could argue maybe burying it deep underground could work, that doesn't get rid of the cost factor, which goes up substantially, even worse, it doesn't solve the problem, a differential of just 1 degree k along the tube under a vacuum (even a "light" one) would within 95% certainty cause implosion... So, the only way to fix the temperature problem would probably be to put a massive heat-exchanger to the entire outside of the tube, while deep underground, and a series of tens of millions of computers thermally regulating each square inch of the tube within 1 degree, fixed near enough to each space to avoid latency issues, even after those quadrillions of dollars are spent building it, it wouldn't be at all resistant to earthquakes or a bomb going off nearby, or a stray shark banging into its side with a force greater than a few newtons.

Your explanation of the physics eddy-current braking and energy dissipation is very much wrong. First of all there are two "magnetic poles" induced in copper under each permanent magnet pole whilst they are set in rotational motion: one "supporting" eddy, and another one "resisting" eddy. Both originate from the tendency of metals to not like the change of magnetic fields and induce currents in a way to oppose the change (Lenz's rule). Those eddies with counter-circulating induced currents try to be symmetrical relative to the centre of the pole but can do so only at very low rotor speeds. Second, induced currents modify the original field (the phenomenon referred to as an "armature reaction"), this causes resulting magnetic field to "lag behind": permanent magnet pole is ahead, but the net field in copper and on the surface of copper is actually slightly behind of the magnets (you state the opposite). At very high rotational speed the induced eddy-currents are distorted so much, that the "resisting" eddy actually circulates exactly around the corresponding pole, and the "supporting" eddies are pushed into the inter-pole space (where the transverse Holbach-array's magnet is sitting). And in this situation it is indeed acts as a mirror image of the pole, pretty much shielding the interior of enclosed copper from the magnetic field. Fourth: energy is dissipated due to the fact of finite resistivity of copper, not because the mirror image is not perfect. If you had a high-temperature superconducting plate instead of copper and could freeze-in the field of magnets by the process called "field-cooling", you wont need to rotate the magnets and supercurrents induced during the process of the superconducting transition would to a great deal create a very stable mirror-image of the field of the magnet. And of course no energy would be dissipated, due to infinite conductivity of the superconductor.

Why not go all solid state no moving parts no heavy expensive neodymium magnets and no bearings or shaft I bet you could shed maybe 75 pounds from the table.

Im guessing these were 3 phase induction motors. They create a moving/rotating magnetic field that causes the rotor to spin by causing eddy currents in the rotor that in turn push against the rotating magnetic field. So now the rotor is spinning, it spins an array of expensive magnets.

To go solid sate, dump the magnets. Dump the motors, dump the bearings, dump the shaft. Instead, add coils as if to making 4 separate 3 phase axial flux induction motors sharing the same bottom non-conducting stator plate. Their roating magnetic fields will induce eddy currents in the copper floor bellow.

Time for some technical info.
Changing magnetic fields induce currents which themselves behave like temporary magnets.
but the polarity of these magnets depend upon whether the applied field (in this example, the field from the magnets of the rotor) is increasing or decreasing.
you could divide the copper plate below into small small square pieces (mentally). As the rotors rotate above them, the magnetic field the magnetic field through each piece keeps changing (due to non uniformity of the field). But here is the real kicker.
The magnetic field not just increases but also decreases. so during one case the induced currents repel the magnets but during other times, they attract them. Then how does it work?
The same goes with his earlier episode (where he used an AC to levitate an aluminum foil)
The current increases and decreases, so during half the time the induced currents in the foil attract the coil and the rest half they repel.
In both cases, on an average the net force must be zero. And levitation shouldn't work. But here we are, seeing is believing.

Wow this could technically make hovering cars. Put those spinning magnet arrays along the base of the vehicle, add compressed air tanks for thrust, cover the road with tracks of sheet metal (I supposed if it's not copper it might get too hot, but perhaps aluminum might be alright.) and there you go: hover cars.
But, is this practical? Lining a road with metal is probably too expensive, even if it's only channels like a rail rather than the whole lane width. Acceleration would probably be quite slow, maybe good momentum for efficient linear travel... until you need to stop. No locked tires to grip the road, so what, another thruster on the front to push the opposite direction? That would be a very slow deceleration. Even if the spinning magnets are immediately braked, the cards would slide along the metal tracks for a while before stopping.
So I guess it's best in monorail type controlled environment rather than personal transportation. Still really cool though.

As much as I would like to see the hyper tube a reality it has one fatal flaw. The fact that it has to maintain such a low pressure environment to make it efficient. All it takes it some idiot to shoot at it or a large enough object to breach the shell by falling on it. This is a problem because once you breach it's structural integrity you get an implosion which is a large potential hazard. There's also the matter of extracting trapped passengers if one should fail in mid transit. How does one go about affixing emergency access ports to a large tube that's under vacuum?

That said I could see the possibility of hovering vehicles if the roadways were made of aluminum. It's abundant enough and relatively low cost when you consider the low level of maintenance. It's not a bad concept. This of course leaves those who like to drive off road for whom this technology just doesn't work. I know there's iron in the dirt but it's extremely unlikely that it would have nearly the consistency that would be necessary to support levitation. It would be more apt to simply stick in large clumps to the spinning magnetic fields and cause an imbalance of the device making it fail. For devices whereas the field is controlled by electromagnets I would imagine the iron dust would chew through any potting of the windings eventually rendering them a death blow.

A fascinating explanatory video.

However, while this is a very cute Party Trick, it has no future as a Transportation Technology.

The "side-effect" which results in heating of the Conductor by the Eddy-Currents means that this Magnetic Levitation stunt is not nearly as ENERGY-EFFICIENT as a Steel Wheel rolling over a Steel Rail ; let alone a Boat floating on Water.

Nobody has ever carried unsubsidised Passenges or Freight on any Mag-Lev Train, anywhere on Earth, and conventional Railways are already failing financially, due to the cost of maintenance against the effects of Global Warming... (Australian Wheatfarmers currently have a bumper Crop which can't be harvested, due to fear of Machinery sparking uncontrolable fires duting the current Heat-Wave...; and meanwhile the Freight Railways have to shut down every time the Ambient Air-Temperature exceeds 35 Degrees Celsius - because the Rails can't cope with the Loaded Weight while under excess Thermal Stress.

Basically, Magnetic Levitation is as useless as Tits on a Bull.
